node.plaintext:
Brooklyn Zelenka presented the work we're doing at Fission at Speakeasy JS
[https://speakeasyjs.com/]  which is "the meetup for ü•º mad science, üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
hacking, and üß™ experiments". 

WebNative: How to put a full stack directly in the browser
Slides are available on Notist ¬ª
[https://noti.st/expede/lZJZIu/webnative-how-to-put-a-full-stack-directly-in-the-browser]
Yes we have stickers
[https://shop.fission.codes/collections/stickers-prints/products/speakeasyjs-jan-2021-js-se-stickers?variant=37714267766952]
: we made a special edition of JavaScript and Speakeasy JS related stickers.
Code SPEAKEASYJS  for a limited number of free sticker packs available (just pay
shipping to wherever you are).

Thanks Feross [https://feross.org/]  for organizing!

Video
Visit the Fission Vimeo account for all of our videos
[https://vimeo.com/fission], or subscribe to our YouTube channel
[https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCkf7isShsKRvQl2J7vz5EaA/featured].

WebNative: How to put a full stack directly in the browser

Yes we have stickers: we made a special edition of JavaScript and Speakeasy JS related stickers. Code SPEAKEASYJS for a limited number of free sticker packs available (just pay shipping to wherever you are).

node.title: Web Native Database Community Kickoff
node.excerpt: We held our first community meeting about building out the distributed database capabilities of the Web Native File System. Video from Jan 7, 2021.
node.custom_excerpt: We held our first community meeting about building out the distributed database capabilities of the Web Native File System. Video from Jan 7, 2021.

authors.name: FISSION Team
authors.bio: Exploring fundamental shifts in the way we host, deploy, and run software for humans, using decentralized web technologies.

primary_author.name: FISSION Team
primary_author.bio: Exploring fundamental shifts in the way we host, deploy, and run software for humans, using decentralized web technologies.

node.plaintext:
We held our first community meeting about interest in building out the
distributed database capabilities of the Web Native File System (WNFS).

Here is the video from the January 7th, 2021 meeting:

James posted notes from the kickoff
[https://talk.fission.codes/t/kicking-things-off/1372]:

 * As we had predicted, the group was a mix of people who are interested in
   using WNDB as app developers (who have feature and API design interests) and
   those interested in the protocol / ‚Äúplumbing‚Äù of WNDB
 * There were not a lot of strong feelings about the nature of the API - rather,
   WNDB needs features and documentation on how to implement them
 * There is a lot of interest / consensus around our initial event source-based
   design ideas. Brooklyn highlighted datomic
   [https://tonsky.me/blog/unofficial-guide-to-datomic-internals/]  and 
   datascript [https://github.com/tonsky/datascript].
 * A lot of good (early) discussion around schema management: developers should
   be able to define them (but also share and re-use), they should be applied as
   ‚Äúviews‚Äù, and lots of interest in project cambria
   [https://www.inkandswitch.com/cambria.html]

We've got a new Webnative DB category in the forum
[https://talk.fission.codes/c/developers/webnative-db/53]  that you can
subscribe to and follow along, as well as join the Fission Discord chat
[https://fission.codes/discord].
node.html:
We held our first community meeting about interest in building out the distributed database capabilities of the Web Native File System (WNFS).

Here is the video from the January 7th, 2021 meeting:

James posted notes from the kickoff:

  • As we had predicted, the group was a mix of people who are interested in using WNDB as app developers (who have feature and API design interests) and those interested in the protocol / ‚Äúplumbing‚Äù of WNDB
  • There were not a lot of strong feelings about the nature of the API - rather, WNDB needs features and documentation on how to implement them
  • There is a lot of interest / consensus around our initial event source-based design ideas. Brooklyn highlighted datomic and datascript.
  • A lot of good (early) discussion around schema management: developers should be able to define them (but also share and re-use), they should be applied as ‚Äúviews‚Äù, and lots of interest in project cambria

We've got a new Webnative DB category in the forum that you can subscribe to and follow along, as well as join the Fission Discord chat.

node.title: Web Native File System Technical Design Overview
node.excerpt: Brooklyn and Daniel from the Fission team present a technical overview of the Web Native File System.
node.custom_excerpt: Brooklyn and Daniel from the Fission team present a technical overview of the Web Native File System.

authors.name: FISSION Team
authors.bio: Exploring fundamental shifts in the way we host, deploy, and run software for humans, using decentralized web technologies.

authors.name: Brooklyn Zelenka
authors.bio: CTO at Fission ‚ô•Œª Programs with functions

primary_author.name: FISSION Team
primary_author.bio: Exploring fundamental shifts in the way we host, deploy, and run software for humans, using decentralized web technologies.

node.plaintext:
Fission has designed a spec for what we call the Web Native File System (WNFS).
It is implemented on top of IPFS and can be loaded in any browser, including
mobile.

We‚Äôve designed the system to store metadata, encrypt private files, and offer a
number of features for end users and developers using the file system to build
web apps with a web native file system, where files are owned by users. This
also leads to a style of single tenant architecture for web apps, but for this
presentation we will focus mainly on the file system details.

Join Brooklyn Zelenka and Daniel Holmgren as they present a technical design
overview of WNFS. Leave a comment in the forum
[https://talk.fission.codes/t/fission-s-web-native-file-system-technical-design-overview-with-daniel-and-brooklyn/818https://talk.fission.codes/t/fission-s-web-native-file-system-technical-design-overview-with-daniel-and-brooklyn/818] 
 if you have questions.

Slides
Full Slide deck available on Notist ¬ª
[https://noti.st/expede/QAYFyW/webnative-file-system]Screencast
Sorry, your browser doesn't support embedded videos.Video
Resources
 * Slides on Notist [https://noti.st/expede/QAYFyW/webnative-file-system]
 * Fission Whitepaper
   [https://whitepaper.fission.codes/file-system/file-system-basics]  (continues
   to be a living document)
 * Implemented in webnative SDK on Github
   [https://github.com/fission-suite/webnative], with basic info in the README 
 * Extended usage and documentation in the Fission Guide
   [https://guide.fission.codes/webnative-sdk/getting-started-webnative-sdk]
node.html:
Fission has designed a spec for what we call the Web Native File System (WNFS). It is implemented on top of IPFS and can be loaded in any browser, including mobile.

We‚Äôve designed the system to store metadata, encrypt private files, and offer a number of features for end users and developers using the file system to build web apps with a web native file system, where files are owned by users. This also leads to a style of single tenant architecture for web apps, but for this presentation we will focus mainly on the file system details.

Join Brooklyn Zelenka and Daniel Holmgren as they present a technical design overview of WNFS. Leave a comment in the forum if you have questions.

Screencast

Video

Resources

  • Slides on Notist
  • Fission Whitepaper (continues to be a living document)
  • Implemented in webnative SDK on Github, with basic info in the README
  • Extended usage and documentation in the Fission Guide
